import React from 'react'; import './Steps.css'; // Import CSS file for styling const backgroundImageUrl = 'https://media.rnib.org.uk/images/The_Happy_Hour_37_Happy_Hour_Podcast_37_Comba.width-1000.jpg'; const StayConnected = () => { return (

Stay Connected

Staying connected to supportive organizations and communities can significantly ease the journey of adapting to vision loss. It's common to initially feel isolated and alone, but connecting with others who share similar experiences can normalize your feelings and provide invaluable support.

Whether through organized support groups, community events, or online forums, these connections offer a sense of belonging and understanding. Engaging with peer-led groups and community organizations not only provides practical advice and resources but also fosters a sense of hope and possibility.

By embracing these connections, individuals can find strength in the community and realize that they are part of a network that supports and empowers them.

Listen to Carl's story:

Find your community:

You'll find your community through tons of great resources. Check out these examples:

Local Organizations
  • Center For Independence of the Disabled, New York
  • VISIONS/Services for the Blind and Visually Impaired
  • VIA: Visually Impaired Advancement
Government Services:

Counselors also work with families to help them understand the challenges their loved one is facing. They provide guidance on how to support their family member and adjust to changes together, fostering a supportive home environment.

  • Visions Support Groups/Counseling Services
  • APH FamilyConnect Â®
  • AHRC New York City Family Counseling
Support Groups and Peer Networks:

Counselors educate both individuals and families about what to expect and how to manage daily life with vision loss. They offer practical advice and resources to help navigate this new chapter effectively.

  • Helen Keller National Center Individualized Counseling and Support Groups
  • Low Vision Occupational Therapy Services
  • American Foundation for the Blind (AFB) counselling
); } export default StayConnected;
